component:ember-data-autocomplete-js/pod.title: Autocomplete
component:ember-data-autocomplete-js/pod.text: This {{autocomplete}} component is a textbox powered by autocomplete.js and Ember Data's store in fetching type ahead completion results that your user can choose.

attributes.name: Autocomplete
attributes.description: This {{autocomplete}} component is a textbox powered by autocomplete.js and Ember Data's store in fetching type ahead completion results that your user can choose.

fields.name: store
fields.description: The Ember Data store service that is used to query the data.

fields.name: _autocompleteInstance
fields.description:
DO NOT TOUCH.

The Autocomplete instance that is created on didInsertElement.

methods.name: autocompleted
methods.description: Triggered when the query is autocompleted. Autocompleted means the query was changed to the hint. The event handler will be invoked with 3 arguments: the jQuery event object, the suggestion object, and the name of the dataset the suggestion belongs to.

methods.name: closed
methods.description: Triggered when the dropdown menu of the autocomplete is closed.

methods.name: cursorChanged
methods.description: Triggered when the dropdown menu cursor is moved to a different suggestion. The event handler will be invoked with 3 arguments: the jQuery event object, the suggestion object, and the name of the dataset the suggestion belongs to.

methods.name: cursorRemoved
methods.description: Triggered when the cursor leaves the selections or its current index is lower than 0.

methods.name: empty
methods.description: Triggered when all datasets are empty.

methods.name: opened
methods.description: Triggered when the dropdown menu of the autocomplete is opened.

methods.name: redrawn
methods.description: Triggered when appendTo is used and the wrapper is resized/repositionned.

methods.name: selected
methods.description: Triggered when a suggestion from the dropdown menu is selected. The event handler will be invoked with the following arguments: the jQuery event object, the suggestion object, the name of the dataset the suggestion belongs to and a context object. The context contains a .selectionMethod key that can be either click, enterKey, tabKey or blur, depending how the suggestion was selected.

methods.name: shown
methods.description: Triggered when the dropdown menu of the autocomplete is shown (opened and non-empty).

methods.name: updated
methods.description: Triggered when a dataset is rendered.

methods.name: willDestroy
methods.description: Destroy the #_autocompleteInstance instance that was created during #didInsertElement.

methods.name: _fixAutofocus
methods.description: Fixes Ember's weird bug where autofocus can't be re-triggered on subsequent transitions.

methods.name: _initializeAutocomplete
methods.description: Responsible for locating this component's <input> element and passing it to Algolia's autocomplete.js library for initialisation.

accessors.name: _selector
accessors.description: The html #id selector of this component used to instantiate the Autocomplete instance.

arguments.name: additionalFilters
arguments.description:
Optional.

A hash containing any additional filters that may be required to filter the returned autocomplete results.

<Autocomplete ... @additionalFilters=(hash by_active=true) ... />

arguments.name: displayKey
arguments.description:
Required. Defaults to "id".

The derived value that will be set in the texbox upon choosing an item. If the suggestion argument is not supplied, then the displayKey derived value will also be presented in the suggestions list that appears beneath the autocomplete textbox.

arguments.name: filter
arguments.description:
Required.

The name of the filter that will be passed whatever the user keys into the textbox.

<Autocomplete ... @filter="by_name_search" ... />

arguments.name: include
arguments.description:
Optional.

The comma separated list of dasherized relationship names that should be side-loaded (included) in the JSON-API payload response.

<Autocomplete ... @include="roles" ... />

arguments.name: modelName
arguments.description:
Required.

The dasherized Ember Data model name that will be queried for autocomplete results.

<Autocomplete ... @modelName="user" ... />

arguments.name: page
arguments.description:
Required. Experimental.

You can control how many records are being returned by your JSON-API endpoint by passing the page size.

arguments.name: sort
arguments.description:
Optional.

The comma separated list of dasherized attribute names that will be used to sort the results server side.

<Autocomplete ... @sort="last-name,first-name,email" ... />

arguments.name: suggestion
arguments.description:
Optional.

The suggestion value that will be rendered in the list of options that appears beneath the autocomplete textbox. We suggest wrapping your value with <p> tag.

The best was to implement this function is in the Component or Controller of the template that this is being rendered in.

For example:

 // app/controllers/.../somewhere.js
 suggestByFirstAndLastName: function(model) {
   return `<p>${model.firstName} ${model.lastName}</p>`;
 }
 <Autocomplete ... @suggestion=suggestByFirstAndLastName/>

arguments.name: globalOptions
arguments.description:
The globalOptions for the autocomplete initialization.

TODO: should these be merge-able?
arguments.type: {dropdownMenuContainer: null, keyboardShortcuts: Array, debug: boolean, cssClasses: {cursor: string, dropdownMenu: string, input: string, prefix: string, hint: string, root: string, suggestion: string, suggestions: string, dataset: string, noPrefix: boolean, empty: string}, minLength: number, templates: {dropdownMenu: null, footer: null, header: null, empty: null}, tabAutocomplete: boolean, ariaLabel: null, clearOnSelected: boolean, autoselectOnBlur: boolean, openOnFocus: boolean, hint: boolean, appendTo: null, autoWidth: boolean, autoselect: boolean}

template:docs/demos/index.title: Basic
template:docs/demos/index.text: Basic Autocomplete Component Begin typing to get a list of user results. Thanks Mirage & Faker!

template:docs/how-it-works.title: How It Works
template:docs/how-it-works.text: How It Works These examples demonstrate component invocation using Angle Brackets and named arguments syntax (`@`). We use the Ember Data store and JSON-API semantics to search for your model results. User Model Let's say in your Ember Data world you have a User model. import DS from 'ember-data'; import { attr } from '@ember-decorators/data'; import { computed } from '@ember-decorators/object' const { Model } = DS; export default class UserModel extends Model { /** Attributes ------------------------------------------------- / @attr('boolean') active; @attr('date') dateOfBirth; @attr('string') email; @attr('string') firstName; @attr('string') lastName; /* Computed ------------------------------------------------- */ @computed('firstName', 'lastName') fullName() { return ${this.firstName} ${this.lastName}; } } Autocomplete Component Perhaps you want to choose a user from an autocomplete text box, below is an example of the component you'd invoke from your template. Autocomplete @displayKey="fullName" @filter="by_name_search" @modelName="user" @selected=(action "onSelected") @sort="last-name,first-name" The <Autocomplete> component extends @ember/component/text-field and you're delivered an <input> element that is wrapped with Algolia's autocomplete after it is inserted into the DOM. Why do you care that it's an input element? Simply because you might want to style it. Should you be using Bootstrap you could add class="form-control" to get some style love. Responding To A Chosen Option You need to bind an action to the @selected attribute which is responsible for doing something with the User instance that is chosen from the autocomplete input. Below is an example of what a typical action will look like. import { action } from '@ember-decorators/object' import Controller from '@ember/controller'; export default class IndexController extends Controller { @action onSelected(event, user, dataset, context) { // do something with the chosen user parameter alert(user.dateOfBirth.toISOString()); return true; } } Autocomplete Component's Use Of The Store So what happened to populate the autocomplete options? Effectively, the Ember Data store was called upon to perform a Ember Storefront's loadRecords (basically an Ember Data query). // ... const textboxValue = this.value; // whatever the user typed const modelName = this.modelName; // => "user" - the @modelName value you passed into the component const filter = this.filter; // => "by_name_search" the @filter value you passed into the component const include = this.include; // => "" the @include value you passed into the component const sort = this.sort; // => "last-name,first-name" the @sort value you passed into the component this.store.loadRecords(modelName { filter: { this.filter: textboxValue }, include: this.include, sort: this.sort }) // ...

template:docs/index.title: Installation
template:docs/index.text: Installation Install Or Upgrade ember install ember-data-autocomplete-js What Happens ember-data-autocomplete-js is downloaded and added to your project. Algolia's autocomplete.js npm package is installed and imported globally. ember-data is installed or upgraded. If you don't want the upgrade make sure to edit your package.json devDependencies rolling back the new ember-data version number. ember-data-storefront is installed because we use its clever loadRecords method to perform queries that populate the autocomplete suggestions.

template:docs/quickstart.title: Quickstart
template:docs/quickstart.text: Quickstart Let's say in your Ember Data world you have a User model. We'll use JSON-API semantics to search your users through Ember Data's store and then render them in the autocomplete control. Below is an example of a template. And below is an example of the controller's action that raises an alert containing a message about the user that was chosen from the autocomplete.js text input. // ... @action onSelected(event, user/, dataset, context/) { alert(You chose ${user.firstName}!!!); return true; } // ...

template:docs/styling.title: Styling
template:docs/styling.text: Styling Styling is trivial and is up to you. Algolia autocomplete.js gives you a helping hand in their look and feel page. Poaching from their site, simply add this to your app/styles/app.css (or app/styles/app.scss if you're using SASS: .algolia-autocomplete { width: 100%; } .algolia-autocomplete .aa-input, .algolia-autocomplete .aa-hint { width: 100%; } .algolia-autocomplete .aa-hint { color: #999; } .algolia-autocomplete .aa-dropdown-menu { width: 100%; background-color: #fff; border: 1px solid #999; border-top: none; } .algolia-autocomplete .aa-dropdown-menu .aa-suggestion { cursor: pointer; padding: 5px 4px; } .algolia-autocomplete .aa-dropdown-menu .aa-suggestion.aa-cursor { background-color: #B2D7FF; } .algolia-autocomplete .aa-dropdown-menu .aa-suggestion em { font-weight: bold; font-style: normal; }

template:index/index-content.title: Motivation
template:index/index-content.text: Motivation Looking for the quickstart? . When we started using Ember back in 2014 Twitter's Typeahead component was quite popular and we incorporated it into our application. Since it's been abandoned Algolia has forked the project at autocomplete.js. This Ember addon wraps the typeahead/autocomplete functionality in a relatively convenient component and uses Ember Data to search your models. Discover An Issue? Search and raise
